bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 17, 1874

div1.p: Reed is exhausted from work. He plans a trip home. His step-mother is curious about his relationship with Emilie Lawrence. He critiques contemporary novels.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, September 17, 1874
div1.p:
I owe you an
apology for my long delay
in answering your last letter.
I would have written you
promtly, had I not been
deterred from so doing by
severe sickness. During three
long weeks I have been
confined to my room, and
during the greater part of
this time, I was scarcely
able to raise my head from
the pillow. Hence I have,
of necessity, been compelled
to forego executing many
plans which I had projected,
no one of which gave me more
reason for regret than my
inability to write to you.
Doubtless, my own folly was
the cause of my indisposition.
I had been trying to do more
than my strength could bear.
It may be that I cannot do
as much brain-work, in
the same length of time, as
I could do in my younger
days; or perhaps a more
correct statement would
be that I have, for so long
a time, abandoned the habit
of hard, continuous appli-
cation, as to make it some-
what difficult, if not a
matter attended with dan-
ger, to return into the “traces”
quickly. I remember the
time when I could study
as much as 20 hours un-
interuptedly, day after day,
and not experience any bad
effect from it, but I pre-
sume that time shall return
no more. “Man wants but
little here below, nor wants
that little long;” thus
sang the sweetest bard
that ever counted Muse;
and, for once, subscribing
to that sentiment, I must
content myself with the
lighter task and leave to
others the greater perfor-
mance. But really there is
a charm in studying that
I fain must acknowledge.
Let me become interestedin
with what the Author is
saying and it is a difficult
matter to “break the spell”;
nor do I cease, till my wea-
ry senses warn me that
nature is well-nigh ex-
hausted. Oh! that we
would always abide by
nature's teachings!
Then indeed would we be
happy, healthy and wise.
Perhaps I decide to dash
aside the book and, for
once, yield to refreshing
sleep; but quicker than
ever winged ligtht light-
ning cleaved Heaven's
vault, the thought flashes
through my mind that
there are a thousand
things in the cast-aside
volume of which I am
ignorant; a thousand
unanswerable questions
that may rise up against
me, in the day of my
examination, to humble
and mortify me.
Wracked by a thousand
fears, I tear open the book
and eagerly scan its pages,
determined to exhaust every
effort, and if need be, to
suffer death rather than
defeat! This is what I
have done, and the result
is sickness, mental pa-
ralysis -- and it is what
I shall not dare repeat.
Too happy in having partially
regained my strength, I
will see to it that I do
not precipitate myself
into my former unhappy
condition. This I can do
the more easily, as I have
an abundance of time in
which to review my studies.
A few days ago I received
a notice from the Pres.
Army Exam. Board that I
would not have to stand
my examination till
Jan. 18th., 1875. Of course,
this suits me exactly, as
it will give me an oppor-
tunity to visit home soon.
I would go home, at once,
but I don't know where
homefolks are, whether
at the Springs or in Mur-
freesboro. As soon as I
hear that they have arrived
at home, I shall “strike
my tents” and follow, unless
something unforeseen detains
me. I assure you that I
highly appreciate the kind
sympathy which you ex-
tended to me. I can study
with a lighter heart, know-
ing that I possess it.
What says the poet? “Ah!
how skillful grows the
hand” -- well, unfortunate
me, that I should forget
the other line, just when
I need it. Never mind, I'll
remember it some other
time and then I'll write
it down before I for-
get it. Still there are some-
things that I do remember,
I know that sympathy is
the golden cord that binds
humanity closer together.
To know that a heart
beats in friendly sympathy
with our own is one of
life's sweetest comforts.
To what noble aims have
not men and women as-
pired, encouraged by this
same knowledge! It is bet-
ter than “good news from
a far country.” It calms
the bosom of the tempest-
tossed mariner, though
all be dark around;
it cheers the warrior's
heart; dispels his fears;
it guides the scholar's pen;
attunes the poet's tongue
to sweetest strains; bids
the down-hearted look
up; the faint be strong,
and wraps the whole
earth in a halo of glory!
I know that I have imposed
upon your patience by
writing so much about
my examination; but I'll
not do this again. At this
moment I bury the sub-
ject a thousand fathoms
deep, nor will I again
resurrect it. I have ever
had the misfortune of
pouring in to my friend's
ears all my anticipations
and fears; a fault which
I admit is not praise-
worthy. Yet it has often
relieved me of half the bur-
den and brought much
comfort to my heart.
I had a letter from my
good mother a few days
before I was taken sick.
She was then enjoying her-
self at the Springs. In
the course of her letter
she expressed a somewhat
faint desire for a more
perfect knowledge of
what I was writing to
you; a desire possibly
attributable to that
feeling of curiosity so
universally prevalent among
the “sons (and daughters) of
men.” In reply, I conveyed
to her my regrets atin not
being able to give her any
definite information on
the subject; at the same time
kindly thanking her for her
parental interest. I further
intimated that when my
letters passed out of my
hands they became the
property of another, and
hence I would refer her to you
for more correct infor-
mation. Of course, her in-
quiry was purely the result
of a harmless curiosity,
and she did not dream
that I would mention it to
you. I must add that
Mrs. R. is, at all times, most
profuse in her praises of
Miss Lawrence, & can scarce
find language to express
her admiration of that lady's
many superlative qualities.
On such occassions her
words fall as thick and
fast as snow-flakes
on a winter's evening. Doubt-
less she knows that she
has a willing auditor --
certainly I have never
entered any denial.
Before concluding, I will
say a word or two on the
“Novel” question which you
were discussing in, your
last letter. There can be
no doubt but that you have
taken the right view of the
question. Your legal friend,
I think, is wrong, for once.
It is not to be supposed
that a man should be
right on every subject.
With your permission, we will
leave him out of sight, for a
few moments. I do not hesi-
tate to say that 98 per ct. of
all novels are second or
third class -- the worst
kind of trashy literature.
We must not wonder at this
when we think of the motives
that lead to their production.
It often happens that some young
man or woman, college-educa-
ted, living in luxury, finds
it difficult to passidle away the time
which hangs so heavily on
his or her hands. Woe be to
the rest of mankind, if the thought
of writing a novel occurs
to them. And how often is
such the case! Again pov-
erty presses some poor
unfortunate & he flies
to his pen for succor.
The result naturally fol-
lows that the production
must be worthless. To
produce a good novel, there
must be a sound, thinking
brain, the faculty of ob-
serving and interpreting, a
profound insight into human
nature and a keen discrim-
ination of character. Well,
how often do we find such
an one? Perhaps, once in
ten thousand instances. I
cannot say more at present.
I have managed to cover
much paper with a very
little that is worth the
knowing. As this is only the
second day that I have been
able to sit up, it has been
something of an effort to
write.
